paper_abstract: One-to-one multiobjective search in graphs deals with the problem of finding all Pareto-optimal solution paths between given start and goal nodes according to a number of distinct noncommensurate objectives. The problem is inherently more complex than single objective graph search. Time requirements are dominated by the facts that (a) many different non-dominated labels may need to be explored for each node; (b) each new label under consideration must be checked for dominance against various subsets of previously generated labels. This paper describes how a dimensionality reduction technique can be applied to exact label-setting algorithms, reducing the number of dominance checks and allowing for much faster multiobjective search. The technique is applied to NAMOA*, a state of the art exact label-setting multiobjective search algorithm, achieving reductions in time requirements of more than an order of magnitude over problems in random grids and realistic road maps. Tests include problems with three, four, and five objectives. (C) 2015 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
paper_title: Dimensionality reduction in multiobjective shortest path search
